If one interprets the constitution as an originalist (as I voted) then there is absolutely no provision in the consitution that would prohibit a state from establishing a religion, restricting speech or the press. The first ammendment makes no mention of state law, only what congress can do. I could be totally wrong, but I have challenged a few people (none lawyers) to prove to me that there is such a thing as "freedom of religion" or "free speech" in the United States according to the consitution. There are no such guarantees. The original wording's purpose was to keep from interfering with states' rights. If a state wanted to restrict speech, then let them, as long as congress wasn't involved (according to the wording). But, using a "living consitution" interpretation, the supreme court has ruled numerous times that, say, teaching creationism in public schools is unconstitutional. They say things like "The Establishment Clause forbids the enactment of any law "respecting an establishment of religion" ." http://www.talkorigins.org/faqs/edwa...lard.html#Held But it doesn't say that. Only if judges re-write the 1st ammendment does it say that. I missed Antonin Scalia. He spoke near here on Monday. I've heard he doesn't like to announce where he'll be speaking. Too bad I missed it. I think he said he was an originalist. He must be against free speech.

*sigh* Using a originalist view, every time application of a law changed, that would mean the consitution would have to have a law added or amended. Has this happened? No. Example, cruel and unusual has changed over the years. The 8th ammendemnet did not include specific means of punishment that we used to use. If there was a origanlist in place, to include such a change would require a law. Was there a law? No, there was not. The Supreme court ruled that _____ was cruel and unusual and therefore outlawed it on the basis of the consitutuion. The interpretation of what constitutied what was cruel and ususual changed without ammending the consitution. So how can you say that the consitution is not a living document when interpretation of it has changed without laws?

You should get in the habit of not assuming. 1) The constution is specifically vague, not to mention that the founders were not originalists either. 2) Legislation requires legislators. Judges rule outside of such. Therefore any ruling outside of the legislature is not legislation, as only they have the ability to legislate laws. It disturbs me you asked that. 3) Easily. Words change over time, while the exactly spelling does not (unless you move from the states to Britain or vice versa), their meanings do as well as interpretations of how those words work together. A document in the early 40s that describes "gay culture" or a happy life, would obviously mean something vastly different today, yet the words themselves haven't changed in respect to their order or spelling, their meanings have. 4) Precedent. Oh wait, they just did get answered. You should get in the habit of not assuming.

ResponseText: On the contrary, I made no such claim. I merely said that the consitution was vague and that the founders were not origanlists. I suggest you read it carefully next time. Judges can strike down laws. They cannot make them. Even in the gay marriage argument, Judges can only strike down bans, they cannot force new laws into existance. The only people who can legislate are those who are in the legislature. I'm still disturbed you asked this. It's basic knowledge of how the government works. Society does, or some major event. It is true in many aspects of life. gay as happy is a archeic term, the english language is full of them, it's just evidence that words change meaning. Legal documents can have their meanings changed. What was previously ruled cruel and unusual changes meaning, as we have seen with the death penalty in the 70s. Precedent can be changed. One can set a new precedent which then may or may not be followed. My answer is unchanged. Self proclamation of incoherenace does not make it so.
